COMBINED REPLY IN SUPPORT OF MOTION TO PARTIALLY LIFT THE STAY OF PROCEEDINGS


${ ^{1}$ City of Cincinnati, et al. v. FirstEnergy Corp., et al., consolidated by order filed Dec. 14, 2020.
${ }^{2}$ State of Ohio ex rel. Dave Yost v. Energy Harbor Corp., et al., consolidated by order filed Dec. 14, 2020.
}

Fustenergy enties, Energy Garbor enties, Gan Cespedes, Charles Jones, Michael Dowlmg, Samuel Randazzo, and Randazzo entities (hereinafter "Responding Defendans") resist the State's request to partally lift the stay in proceedngs primarily on argments that (i) the Agred Order entere into ten months ago, is a contract which this Coun is bared from disurbing at the request of the State, (2) the indicted and mindicted defendants selfinctmination protections are at stake, and (3) FirstEnergy's recent Qefered Prosecution Agreement, revealing an addional branch of bribery related to $\overline{H B}$. 6 involving the fomer Chair of the Fublic Utities Commission of Ohio, is insuffient to show "frad, mistake, or oher extrardinay circmatances" to ment hang the stay in these civil procedngs. Perhans in the wotd of "a gian lobbying frm that nus a wility," admission of bribery of puble state officials and paying a $\$ 230$ million penaly is mother day in the corporate wond, but to the cizens of Ohio it is a big deal, and fuly justice reevaluang the status of the pase placed on the State to have its day in Comt.

Vanous Responding Befendans argue that the Sate is not honoring the terms of the Agreed Order. That is wrong. Save for minor procedural requirements, the State let the case remain stayed and did not pursue discovery. Only dfer FirstEnergy admitted its culpability in the underying HB. 6 scandal, revealing a provable new aspect of the bribery scandal involing the former Chair of the PYCO, did the State seek to lift the stay to add new parties and new clams. Amending of the Complain was precisely justifed based on the change in landscape that was argued in the State's onginal Motion. So too is the State's current Motion to partialy hit the stay Simply put, the origina gromeds for the stay are no longer in offect. As was eviden from the


${ ^{3}$ 'A giant lobbying firm that runs a utility': FirstEnergy's involvement in Ohio politics dates back decades, Columbus Dispatch (Nov. 1, 2021)
 before-hb-6-cormption-case/6007622001/
}

hearing where the parties and the Com discussed the stay, and the language indicating that the parties would regulany check in with the Coun during the stay, the Cout and the partes knew that the grounds could shift, requing the stay to be revisited. FirstEnergy's DPA and the advancing of other civil cases are just such cimamstances.

It is oversimplifed for the Responding Defendants to argue that the State agreed to the stay in "exchange for disconthuation of decouphng charges". (Firstenergy Memo Contra, pg. 4.) It is trae that once the decouplang charges ended, the State sam no basis for the case to advance further at that the, based largely upon this Cour's earler discovery orders based on the pending prosecution. Thus, while the agreements were reached together, it is disingenuous for Firstenerg to now argue that it would have contested ending decompling had the stay not occorred

The stay was based upon the Come's agrement with Firenergy's argument that "\{m\}oving Sorward with discovery now would inevitably impar Girstangy's ability to defend this case and interfere with the govemment's prosecution of the parallek crminak case." (FirstEnergy Motion to Stay Discovery, Dec. 2. 2020, pg. \&) When this Cont granted the discovery say at the preliminary inmotion, it acknowedged that the uncertamy of fure criminal indicments for "unindicted Befendans" was a key factor.
"Wt's clear to the Cout, based on news reports, that this is still an ongoing investigation as well, ... lis quite possible that other individuals may be inplicated in the federal criminal matter
...At some poin discovery will have togo forward; butgiven the eanly stage of all these cases and the interest of the Detondants and the unindicted Befendants" interest as well in defending their case and presenting an adequate effective defense, Ithink that staying all discovery in all three cases is appopriate for right now."
(Tr. Pre Inf, Hrg, Dec 21, 2020, pgs 15-16)
Whe not using Framergy by nane, it can hardy be a stretch of logic to equate "the unindicted Defendants" interest" with a certan "Company A" from the Federal ndictment. Thus,

whie Eirstnergy may now want to cham that it "never cited its own potenat criminal exposure as fustifcation for the stay" (emphasis in original) (FirstEnergy Memo Contra, pg. 8), First Energy chose not to chafy that position when this Cout was beheving otherwise and granted the stay that Fratenergy requested nearly a year ago.

Recall that that the Agreed Order was entered into just a few weeks before this Cout was to review its discovery stay, and at a time when Firstenergy was using its potental criminal indictment exposure as a sheld. To suggest that the Agreed Order was narowly tailored to decoupling and wholly uncomected to the Federal ommat case aganat Fret Energy is faghable

Energy Garbor and other Responding Defendants press hard the claim that the Agreed Order is a binding contract forever shacking the parties umtil its tems expre, and that this Cout is helpless regarding its own docket and must wait unt "all criminal proceedings" are completed (Energy Farbor Memo Conta, pgs, 3-5) Wowever, the Com did not, and cannot, abandon its responsibilites in favor of any agreement by the parties to the contrary. For all of Energy Garbor's research in "the Tenth District and comts across the comtry" and bluster regarding "hombook law" that Agreed Order is a binding contract, none of the Responding Defendants' cited cases imolved agted orders regarding stays of procedings. The reled upon cases involved some compromise exchusvely between pattes and did not requte the thal coun to give un is own rights over the docket. State ex rel. Yost v Smmer Roys, The., 10 th Dist Frandin Nos. 18AB-929, 19AB-133, 2019-Oho-3007, f13 (recenership); Klen v, Botho, 24 Dist Montgonery No
 22172,2008 Ohio-1980, 143 (conditional dismissal based on execution of contract), Reik 1. Bowden, 172 Oho App $3 \mathrm{~d} 12,2007$ Ohio-2533,872NE $2 \mathrm{~d} 1253,42$ (1st Wist.) (Cha suppot); Hoyes v. White, 7th Dist. Columbiana No. 016011,200 -Ohio-3467, 12 (ton settement), Ciy

payments of property) A cout is master of its docket, not the parties. The State never considered the stay to be a contract, simply a mere reflection of the status of the case that then existed.

Defendants' fature to cite a single case imvolving a stay being interpreted as a binding contract that terminated this Cout's anthority to contro its own docke speaks volumes.

Although they admit that they hold no Fith Amendment nghts as corporations, FirstEnergy and Energy Habor nevertheless argue that they seek to protect the fights of their natura person co-Defendants, and by extersion, any Fhth Amendment rights involed in discovery by those individuals would potentilly ham the corporate defendans" abilty to defend themselves. (EirstEnergy Memo Contra, pgs. 8-9 and Energy Haborpgs. 7nio.) Simiany, unindicted natural defendants Jones and Bowhing also seek to raise the shed of their indicted codefendans for their own defense. (Jones and Dowheg Meno Contra, pgs. 7.9) But as explaned in the State's underying Motion, both state and federal courts are in accord hat Eith Amendment protections are not a safe harbor from beng called to answer in a companion civil mater. Stote ex rel. Verhovec $\boldsymbol{v}$ Mascio, 81 Ohio $3430334,336,1998$ Ohio-43\}, $691 \mathrm{NE} 20282(1098$, followed,
 ("Oho law is clear that the protection against compulsory self-ncrimination does not extend to prohbit civil hitgation where the possibility of prosection exists, nor does it require staying a related civa case unti a criminal appeal is resolved."

Thus, nether indioted defendants Gouseholder and Boges, nor mindiched defendants Bones, Dowling, and Randazzo, have any Fith Amendment protections in thas civil RCO mater. Consequenty, if there is no Fifth Amendment natura person protection during the pendency of a

civit matter, then it certanly canoo be an extension to mon-natural persons or mindicted pates. The defendants to this case should no longer be protected by the general stay. Responding Defendants' legal support is inapposite.

In Batrd y Daniels, SD Oho No $112-6 \mathrm{~g}-945,2013$ US Dist. LEXIS 16576 (Feb. 7 , 2013), the defendants were wo individuals and eight companies, which were jointy or patially run by one of the defendants. Logically, the assertion of the Fith Amendment privilege by a corporate oftcer will impara a corporate defendant's ability to defend itself. (Id. at *11) Similar issues played out in other cases cted by Responding Defendants. Th re Adelpha Commons, Secs. Witgation, EDPa. No. 02~1781, 2003 U.S. Dist. [EXXS 9736, at 20 (May 13, 2003) ("many of the individual defendants were officers of Adephia and the chams against them arise ont of their conduct at the company"); Bonner Corp. v. Balogh, 819F. Supp 811, 812 (E. D. Wis. 1993) (Fomer employecs alleged to have stolen corporate propenty, ; Parker w. Donson, E BN Y Nos. O6CV-
 LEXIS 63068, at *3 (Aug. 27, 2007) (Sole shareholder and president of two investnent advisory corporations accused of diverting milhons in chent funds from investment accounts into corporate acconts.); Am, Express Business Fin. Corp $v$ RW Professonal Yeasing Servs. Corp, 225 F.Supp 20263,265 (EB N.Y.2002) (RW Professional clams that the ondy cmployees capable of responding to discovery are the individual defendans.") (Emphasis Added.) Only two natual defendants in this case are fomer officers of defendants and there is no clam that only lones and Dowing are capable of responding to FirstEnergy discovery.

To the extent that Responding Defendants beheve that a partial stay which continues to hot Wousehoder and Borges at arm's length from this case "exacebates the prejudice" (ErstEnergy Memo Contra, pg. 9), phaces them "in an unair predicament" (Energy Habor Memo

Conta, pg. 1] ) or treats some defendans diferenty than others (Randazo Memo Contra, pg. 8), they are free to argue that the stay should be complete, rather than partial. But, as was apparent from the State's Motion, the State sought the partial hft to be mindful of those parties whose ongong cmmon procedings have not been resolved If implemenation is a concem (Randazoo Memo Contra, pg 4), this Court is capable of cating a sheduling order that balances the rights of all the parties while allowing some discovery to move foward.

Interestingly, Energy Harbor points out "[d]iscovery in this case is a cross-section of eightlane highway, given the number of panies and non-partes (which inchudes over 70 members of the General Assembly) who wit uknately partichate in very complicated discovery, both in tems of substance and process." (Energy Harbor Nemo Contra, pgs. 2-3.) Jones and Dowing recently indicated that they too believe the breadth of discovery in defending the fundamental allegations of HE 6 extends to numerous pubtic offciaks. Thus, the nomber of potemtal winesses, makes lifing the say even more justifed, not less. Morover, wating to get knee-deep in documents, which by some accouts could number in the milions, justifes lifing the stay now, not contining to sit ide while the criminal case plays on potentilly years into the fure.
 commpelled to bo in Federal Court.


${ ^{4}$ Fired FirstEnergy execs say Jon Husted, others may have info to help them in a civil suit, Columbus Dispatch (Nov. 23, 2021) ("Aside from [Ohio Lt. Gov. Jon] Husted, Jones and Dowling believe discoverable information is held by: FirstEnergy managers and board members, Public Utilities Commission of Ohio members and staff, former Ohio House Speaker Larry Householder, lawmakers who voted for House Bill 6, lobbyist Josh Rubin, political consultant Mike Dawson, and legislative staff members Pat Tully and Frank Strigari.") htos:/www dispach com/story/news/2021/1/23/frstenergy-husted-may-have-infociv-lawsuit-documento-say/8737147002!
${ }^{5}$ Feds to Matt Borges: Check the 1.5 million documents on the Ohio bribery case already sent, The Cincinnati Enquirer (Nov. 12, 2021)
 federalinvestigation 8589091002
}

Fistenergy complain that the federal higation discovery is not "in the normal course" and has ony just begun. Imporanty, FintEnergy also argues that the federal discovery cannot close until the criminal proceedngs end. (FirstEnergy Memo Contra, pg. 10) The potential delay to the cosing of federal discovery is not a reason to delay begmong state discovery,

Moreover, the inference, suggested by Responding Defendants, that once the criminal case is resolved, that magically the civil htigation here will move smoothly is an llusion. Where discovery has been permitted, FirstEnergy has been aggressively resisting'. There is simply no reason to believe that FretEnergy will be more amenable to discovery in "years" cumenty frecasted for this case to conthue unti "fanal resolution of all criminal proceedings."

For its part, Energy Garbor clams that the State is not missing out on the discovery being exchanged in the federal civil cases, whoh is subject to a stipulated protective order, and to which Fousehotder and oher detendats are not named pattes. (Enegy Garbor Memo Contra, pg. 35) This is a non sequitur. Federal case discovery is at least moving forward. And whele the sate may not have access to that discovery it should not be dened the opportuity for its own.

D. Conchusion.

Biscovery is proceeding in oher fora. The State is highy interested in being the prime mover in cleaning up the shameful public comption that has blemished the State. It should not be kept in the dark, while private plamifts and actors before the Puco receive discovery.

For the reasons stated in the State Motion's prevonsly filed and this Reply herein, the request for partaly liting the stay of proceeding should be granted.

Respectfully submitted,
